question: 1 (h)
sols_html:
The alternating series test says that, given a series

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^n a_n\end{aligned}\]

where \(a_n\) is a positive sequence such that \(\lim_{n\to \infty} a_n = 0\), then we have that the series converges. In our case, so long as \(p > 0\), this satisfies the conditions of the alternating series test and so it converges. For \(p \leq 0\), the sequence \(1/n^p\) does not converge to zero, and so the sequence diverges.

Thus the series converges for all \(p > 0\).
